title: Pluto is the Ninth Planet
originalTeaching: Pluto was classified as the ninth planet in our solar system.
explanation: Pluto was reclassified as a 'dwarf planet' by the International Astronomical Union in 2006.

title: Humans Only Use 10% of Their Brain
originalTeaching: The human brain is only using 10% of its capacity at any given time.
explanation: Brain imaging studies show that we use virtually every part of the brain, and most of the brain is active almost all the time.

title: Columbus Discovered America
originalTeaching: Christopher Columbus discovered America in 1492.
explanation: Indigenous peoples lived in the Americas for thousands of years before Columbus, and Norse explorers reached North America around 1000 AD.

title: Dinosaurs Are Extinct
originalTeaching: All dinosaurs died out 65 million years ago.
explanation: Birds are descendants of theropod dinosaurs, meaning dinosaurs are not entirely extinct.

title: Dinosaurs Looked Like Big Lizards
originalTeaching: Dinosaurs were scaly reptiles resembling large lizards.
explanation: Many dinosaurs had feathers and were colorful, as evidenced by fossils like Sinosauropteryx.

title: Brontosaurus Is Not a Dinosaur
originalTeaching: Brontosaurus is the same as Apatosaurus and not a valid name.
explanation: A 2015 study reinstated Brontosaurus as a distinct genus based on morphological differences.

title: George Washington Had Wooden Teeth
originalTeaching: George Washington's dentures were made of wood.
explanation: His dentures were made from ivory, gold, lead, and human or animal teeth; the wood myth arose from stained ivory.

title: Salem Witches Were Burned at the Stake
originalTeaching: Women accused of witchcraft in Salem were burned at the stake.
explanation: Nineteen were hanged and one was crushed; no one was burned, following English law.

title: There Are Three States of Matter
originalTeaching: Matter exists in three states: solid, liquid, and gas.
explanation: Plasma was discovered as the fourth state of matter by Sir William Crookes in 1879.

title: Toilets Flush Opposite in the Southern Hemisphere
originalTeaching: Due to the Coriolis effect, toilets flush in the opposite direction in the Southern Hemisphere.
explanation: The Coriolis effect is too weak to influence toilet flushing; direction is determined by bowl design.

title: Neanderthals Were Less Intelligent Than Humans
originalTeaching: Neanderthals were inferior and less smart than modern humans.
explanation: Research shows Neanderthals were as intelligent, with evidence of art, tools, and jewelry.

title: People Are Left-Brained or Right-Brained
originalTeaching: Personality traits are determined by dominance of the left or right brain hemisphere.
explanation: A 2013 University of Utah study found no evidence for hemispheric dominance in personality.

title: Blood Is Blue When Deoxygenated
originalTeaching: Deoxygenated blood is blue until it hits oxygen.
explanation: Blood is always red; veins appear blue due to how light penetrates the skin.

title: Napoleon Was Short
originalTeaching: Napoleon Bonaparte was unusually short for a man.
explanation: He was about 5 feet 7 inches, average for his time; the myth originated from British propaganda.

title: Humans Have Five Senses
originalTeaching: There are only five human senses: sight, hearing, taste, smell, and touch.
explanation: There are additional senses like proprioception, balance, and thermoception.

title: The Tongue Has a Taste Map
originalTeaching: Different parts of the tongue detect specific tastes like sweet or bitter.
explanation: All tastes can be detected across the entire tongue, as shown by Virginia Collins' study.

title: Swallowed Gum Takes 7 Years to Digest
originalTeaching: If you swallow gum, it stays in your stomach for seven years.
explanation: Gum passes through the digestive system in about a week, like other indigestible items.

title: Hair and Nails Grow After Death
originalTeaching: Hair and fingernails continue to grow after a person dies.
explanation: They appear longer due to skin dehydration and shrinkage, not growth.

title: Thomas Edison Invented the Lightbulb
originalTeaching: Thomas Edison was the sole inventor of the incandescent lightbulb.
explanation: He improved existing designs; Humphry Davy created the first in 1802, Joseph Swan in 1860.

title: I Before E Except After C
originalTeaching: The spelling rule 'I before E except after C' always applies.
explanation: There are numerous exceptions like 'weird' and 'science,' making the rule unreliable.

title: Great Wall Visible from Space
originalTeaching: The Great Wall of China is the only man-made structure visible from space.
explanation: It is not visible without magnification; astronauts confirmed this in 2003.

title: Paper Can't Be Folded More Than 7 Times
originalTeaching: It is impossible to fold a piece of paper in half more than seven times.
explanation: Britney Gallivan folded paper 12 times in 2002 using a large sheet.

title: Bats Are Blind
originalTeaching: Bats are completely blind and rely solely on echolocation.
explanation: All bats have vision; some have excellent eyesight for low light.

title: Bulls Are Enraged by Red
originalTeaching: Bulls become angry and charge when they see the color red.
explanation: Bulls are colorblind to red and react to movement; confirmed by MythBusters in 2007.

title: Going Out with Wet Hair Causes Colds
originalTeaching: Exposing yourself to cold with wet hair will make you catch a cold.
explanation: Colds are caused by viruses, not temperature or wet hair.

title: Cracking Knuckles Causes Arthritis
originalTeaching: Habitually cracking your knuckles will lead to arthritis.
explanation: A 2011 study found no link between knuckle cracking and arthritis.

title: The 5-Second Rule for Dropped Food
originalTeaching: Food is safe to eat if picked up within 5 seconds of dropping.
explanation: Bacteria transfer instantly; a 2016 Rutgers study debunked it.

title: The Food Pyramid is the Best Nutrition Guide
originalTeaching: The USDA Food Pyramid accurately represents healthy eating proportions.
explanation: Replaced by MyPlate in 2011 for a simpler, more accurate representation.

title: Scientists Predicted Global Cooling in the 1970s
originalTeaching: In the 1970s, the scientific consensus was for global cooling and an ice age.
explanation: A 2008 study showed it was a myth; most papers predicted warming.

title: Junk DNA Has No Function
originalTeaching: Non-coding DNA is useless 'junk' without purpose.
explanation: The ENCODE project in 2012 revealed functions in regulatory roles.

title: There Is a Dark Side of the Moon
originalTeaching: The far side of the Moon is perpetually dark and never sees sunlight.
explanation: The Luna 3 spacecraft in 1959 photographed the far side, showing it receives sunlight.

title: Sugar Makes Kids Hyperactive
originalTeaching: Consuming sugar causes hyperactivity in children.
explanation: A 1994 study in the Journal of Abnormal Child Psychology found no link; it's a myth.

title: Goldfish Have Short Memory
originalTeaching: Goldfish have a memory span of only a few seconds.
explanation: Experiments have shown that goldfish can remember tasks for months, debunking the myth of their short memory.

title: Shaving Makes Hair Thicker
originalTeaching: Shaving hair makes it grow back thicker, coarser, or darker.
explanation: A clinical study in 1928 showed that shaving does not affect hair growth rate, thickness, or color; it only appears thicker due to blunt tips.

title: Carrots Improve Vision
originalTeaching: Eating carrots significantly improves eyesight, especially night vision.
explanation: This myth originated from WWII British propaganda to hide radar technology; while vitamin A in carrots aids eye health, it doesn't enhance vision beyond normal levels.

title: Lightning Never Strikes Twice
originalTeaching: Lightning never strikes the same place twice.
explanation: Lightning can and does strike the same location multiple times, as observed with tall structures like the Empire State Building being hit dozens of times a year.

title: Reading in Dim Light Ruins Eyes
originalTeaching: Reading in low light permanently damages eyesight.
explanation: It may cause temporary eye strain, but no permanent damage; ophthalmologists confirm it doesn't affect long-term vision.

title: Einstein Failed Math
originalTeaching: Albert Einstein failed mathematics in school.
explanation: Einstein excelled in math; the myth likely arose from him failing a university entrance exam at 16, but he was advanced for his age.

title: Vikings Wore Horned Helmets
originalTeaching: Viking warriors wore helmets with horns.
explanation: No archaeological evidence supports this; the image comes from 19th-century opera costumes and romanticized art.

title: Dogs and Cats Are Colorblind
originalTeaching: Dogs and cats cannot see colors.
explanation: They see in shades of blue and green; their color vision is limited but not absent, as shown by behavioral studies.

title: Lemmings Commit Mass Suicide
originalTeaching: Lemmings jump off cliffs in mass suicide during migrations.
explanation: This myth was staged in a 1958 Disney documentary; lemmings may drown accidentally but don't intentionally suicide.

title: Sharks Don't Get Cancer
originalTeaching: Sharks are immune to cancer.
explanation: Tumors have been found in multiple shark species, debunking the claim used to promote shark cartilage supplements.

title: Ostriches Bury Heads in Sand
originalTeaching: Ostriches bury their heads in sand when frightened.
explanation: They lower their heads to the ground to blend in or flip eggs; the myth comes from Pliny the Elder.

title: Warts from Toads
originalTeaching: Handling toads or frogs causes warts.
explanation: Warts are caused by human papillomavirus, not amphibians; the bumpy skin of toads led to the association.

title: Sharks Smell Blood Miles Away
originalTeaching: Sharks can detect a drop of blood from miles away.
explanation: They can detect blood at 1 part per million, but typically from hundreds of meters, not miles, depending on currents.

title: Giraffes Sleep 30 Minutes a Day
originalTeaching: Giraffes only sleep for about 30 minutes per day.
explanation: Studies show they sleep around 4-5 hours in short bursts, similar to other large herbivores.

title: Sharks Die If They Stop Swimming
originalTeaching: All sharks must swim constantly or they die.
explanation: Many sharks can pump water over gills while stationary; only some species need constant motion.

title: Poinsettias Are Deadly Poisonous
originalTeaching: Poinsettia plants are highly toxic and can be fatal if ingested.
explanation: They may cause mild irritation but are not lethal; a study showed no toxicity even in large amounts.

title: HIV From Sex With Monkeys
originalTeaching: HIV originated from humans having sex with monkeys.
explanation: It likely transferred through bushmeat hunting and blood contact, not sexual activity.

title: Humans Evolved From Chimpanzees
originalTeaching: Modern humans directly evolved from chimpanzees.
explanation: Both share a common ancestor from 6-8 million years ago; chimps and humans evolved separately.

title: Penny From Skyscraper Kills
originalTeaching: A penny dropped from the Empire State Building can kill someone below.
explanation: Terminal velocity is too low (about 50 mph) to be lethal; it might sting but not kill.

title: Moon Gravity Causes Tides
originalTeaching: Tides are caused solely by the moon pulling on Earth's water.
explanation: Tides result from gravitational differences across Earth due to moon and sun; it's a differential force.

title: Earth Is Perfect Sphere
originalTeaching: The Earth is a perfect sphere.
explanation: It's an oblate spheroid, flattened at poles and bulging at equator due to rotation.

title: Mount Everest Tallest Mountain
originalTeaching: Mount Everest is the tallest mountain on Earth.
explanation: From base to peak, Mauna Kea is taller (over 33,000 ft vs. Everest's 29,000 ft), though Everest is highest above sea level.

title: Water Conducts Electricity
originalTeaching: Pure water is a good conductor of electricity.
explanation: Pure water is a poor conductor; impurities like salts make it conductive.

title: Global Warming Pause
originalTeaching: Global warming paused in the early 2000s.
explanation: Surface temperatures seemed stable, but oceans absorbed most heat; adjusted data shows no pause.

title: Sahara Largest Desert
originalTeaching: The Sahara is the world's largest desert.
explanation: Antarctica is larger (5.4 million sq mi vs. 3.6 million) and fits the desert definition of low precipitation.

title: Diamonds From Coal
originalTeaching: Diamonds are formed from compressed coal.
explanation: Diamonds form from carbon deep in the mantle, predating most coal; coal rarely subducts deep enough.

title: Middle Ages Flat Earth
originalTeaching: People in the Middle Ages believed the Earth was flat.
explanation: Most scholars since ancient Greeks knew it was round; the myth was popularized in 19th-century writings.

title: Summer Closer to Sun
originalTeaching: Summer occurs when Earth is closer to the sun.
explanation: Seasons are due to Earth's tilt; Northern summer happens when farther from sun but tilted toward it.

title: Batteries in Fridge Last Longer
originalTeaching: Storing batteries in the refrigerator prolongs their life.
explanation: Cold can cause condensation and damage; room temperature is best for modern batteries.

title: Humans and Dinosaurs Coexisted
originalTeaching: Humans lived alongside dinosaurs.
explanation: Dinosaurs went extinct 66 million years ago; humans appeared about 300,000 years ago.

title: Eating Turkey Makes You Sleepy
originalTeaching: Turkey causes drowsiness due to high tryptophan.
explanation: Tryptophan levels are similar to other meats; post-meal sleepiness is from overeating carbs and fats.

title: Flu Shots Give You Flu
originalTeaching: Flu vaccines can cause the flu.
explanation: Vaccines use inactivated virus or proteins; mild symptoms are immune response, not infection.

title: Big Bang Was an Explosion
originalTeaching: The Big Bang was a massive explosion creating the universe.
explanation: It was rapid expansion of space itself, not an explosion in preexisting space.

title: Milk Builds Strong Bones
originalTeaching: Drinking milk ensures strong bones and prevents fractures.
explanation: Studies show no reduction in fracture risk; high dairy may increase bone loss due to acidity.

title: No Gravity in Space
originalTeaching: There is no gravity in outer space.
explanation: Gravity is everywhere; astronauts experience microgravity in orbit, falling around Earth.
